children.subject:
There's no right answer, as everyone has their own views on this. The University doesn't explicitly say you shouldn't pick and choose, but a lot of people think that taking some classes graded makes grad schools think you weren't doing so well in the ones you took P/NP. I personally think if you only took those classes graded in which you got an A, you're fine because you're showing that despite the pandemic you at least managed to do your best in *some* classes. At the same time, we don't know exactly what grad schools will do, so it's always possible that they'll disregard the pandemic and assume you didn't do well in your other classes.

In that case, though, recently someone asked a pretty important question: would you want to go to a school that disregards the circumstances of this semester?

I dont think it is fair for either you or for any grad school to assume that I am "trying to game the system" without knowing all the details. 
Each class has been affected in a different way and each class is different for each student. I will be able to get an A in some of the classes owing to the insane amount of effort that I have put in the first half of the semester and because of the classes changing the grading policies to account for the hardship caused. It is sad to see all of that effort go to waste and have the application disregard an entire semester worth of effort. 

Why would a grad school choose to selectively consider a semester and only in a way that affects the student application.
^in the sense that they will disregard spring 2020 only if you take it as PNP. Otherwise, they will consider it against you.

I don't think the classes you get Ps in will necessarily be "against you". But it will probably be looked at like how PNP classes are looked at during a regular semester(which can be against you. Like if you get all A's and one P, that P would look like you got a C). Adding to what the above comments said, however, I feel like the A would be discounted even if we get all A's this semester. There is a pandemic going on and instructions are heavily disrupted. Tests are online and with other accommodations, it is overall an "easier" semester if you are fortunate enough to not be affected much in your personal life. Of course, not everyone has that privilege and maybe you are going through hard times and still get A's. But given that we all have our unique situation, the grading won't be as fair and I doubt that grad schools will consider any grades gained this semester heavily in your application.

"If I get As in 2/3 of my classes, the grad school will realize that in spite of having a global pandemic, I was able to pull off an A in almost all of my classes."

Yes, but in the case of the remaining 1/3 of classes, they'll assume you were doing poorly and were on track for very low grades, otherwise you wouldn't take these classes P/NP in the first place (assuming they're major requirements/relevant to what you want to do). Yes it's a pandemic semester, but by opting out and choosing to have some classes letter graded, you're basically saying "I know this sucks for a lot of people, but fortunately I'm in the position to still do well in (at least some of) my classes, so I'm going to take them graded" At that point, you've made the decision that you think your classes should be considered instead of discarded, and that decision will affect how Gard schools look at both your graded and P/NPed classes. If you take a major requirement P/NP and take other requirements graded, people *will probably* treat a P as a C-. Everyone is trying to be considerate during these times, but they're not going to take people trying to game the system kindly

history.content:
Hey
I was wondering why does the University advice against taking some as graded and some as PNP?
(From the perspective of grad school).
In my eyes, if
a) I take all as PNP, the grad school will disregard that semester owing to global pandemic
b) If I get As in 2/3 of my classes, the grad school will realize that in spite of having a global pandemic, I was able to pull off an A in almost all of my classes.

Some mentioned that this will lead to grad schools assuming the worst case scenario and hence I chose to PNP other classes, but won't they also consider the fact that it was a pandemic semester!
history.subject: Thoughts of PNP vs letter grade
